messages.content: Explain dog trait "affectionateWithFamily" for breed selection. Keep it practical and informative.

This trait reflects how closely a breed tends to bond with their household. Higher scores (4–5) usually mean a dog that seeks frequent contact, enjoys cuddling, and may prefer company most of the day. Lower scores (1–2) lean more independent. Consider your routine: high-affection dogs do best when people are home often, while more independent breeds tolerate alone time better
Explain dog trait "goodWithKids" for breed selection. Keep it practical and informative.

Dogs with higher scores (4-5) are more tolerant and patient with children's behaviour and are overall family-friendly breeds. Breeds with lower scores are not recommended to families with kids since their level of tolerance is not that big. No matter the score - children should never be left unsupervised with dogs.
Explain dog trait "goodWithOtherDogs" for breed selection. Keep it practical and informative.

This trait says how likely a breed is to be friendly toward other dogs. Some breeds are friendlier toward other dogs both at home and outside. If you have other dogs already you should look for a friendlier breed since meeting is more likely to go better.
Explain dog trait "shedding" for breed selection. Keep it practical and informative.

Shedding level tells us how much hair and fur can you expect in your living space with this breed. Breeds with high shedding will need to be brushed more frequently, are more likely to trigger certain types of allergies, and are more likely to require more consistent vacuuming and lint-rolling.
Explain dog trait "opennessToStrangers" for breed selection. Keep it practical and informative.

Level of how welcoming your dog is can vary depending on the breed. Some breeds with lower score (1-2) will be reserved and cautious around strangers, while other breeds with higher score (4-5) are happy to meet a new human whenever there is one.
Explain dog trait "playfulnessLevel" for breed selection. Keep it practical and informative.

This trait shows us how enthusiastic a breed is likely to be when it comes to playing even after puppy phase. Some breeds are happier to just sit and chill with you on the couch, while others are more likely to ask for playing fetch or tug-of-war.
Explain dog trait "protectiveNature" for breed selection. Keep it practical and informative.

Protective nature is how inclined a breed is to guard home and family. Higher scores (4–5) often mean strong watchdog instincts; lower scores (1–2) fit households that prefer a relaxed greeter over a guard. Training and socialization shape this.
Explain dog trait "adaptabilityLevel" for breed selection. Keep it practical and informative.
This trait shows how easily a breed handles changes - from living conditions, noise, weather and other changes in daily-life and routines.
Explain dog trait "trainability" for breed selection. Keep it practical and informative.

How easy it will be to train your dog and how willing the breed is to learn new things. Some breeds want to please their owner and others are more strong willed and want to do what they want and when they want to do it.
Explain dog trait "energyLevel" for breed selection. Keep it practical and informative.

Tells us how much excersise and mental stimulation this breed needs to feel fullfiled. Some breeds happy to lounge, kind of couch potatoes while others have high energy and need a job or activity to stay happy and healthy. Purpose-bred dogs can have jobs that require decision-making, problem-solving, concentration, or other qualities, and without the brain exercise they need, they'll create their own projects to keep their minds busy
Explain dog trait "barkingLevel" for breed selection. Keep it practical and informative.

How often this breed vocalizes, whether it's with barks or howls. While some breeds will bark at every passer-by or bird in the window, others will only bark in particular situations. Some barkless breeds can still be vocal, using other sounds to express themselves.
